instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-2879: What is 820-2879? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2879</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> one beep
threads.message:
Heya guys

I have this board <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2879</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> .When I bought it boot up once and die. I mean literals just say good bye and never start up again. Except annoying beep  

I opened it there was some funny paper on the RAM but well it doesn't charge battery from start. So I decide first work on it and change isl625 now I am stuck with this RAM problem. On L7330 is 0.22 V
I changed already <CHIP>U7300</CHIP> twice and still same issue. I was thinking to change  <TRANSISTOR>Q7330</TRANSISTOR> as a start point but that mos look OK. Any advice where to start?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2879</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> one beep
threads.message:
Post first diode mode at L7330, red probe to ground.
Also post some voltages for <CHIP>U7300</CHIP>; pins 10, 11, 14, 15.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2879</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> one beep
threads.message:
So L7330 on diode mode 0.270

pin

10:3.30
11:3,28
14:5
15:5

I know I said <TRANSISTOR>Q7330</TRANSISTOR> look ok but pin 3-4 should not have 0.002 on diode mode, right? Its a stupid question but I rather ask and be stupid a minute that stay stupid :D

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2879</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> one beep
threads.message:
"pin 3-4 should not have 0.002 on diode mode, right?"
Not really true.
If <CHIP>U7300</CHIP> detects a problem, it will short G-S of <TRANSISTOR>Q7330</TRANSISTOR>, to avoid any output voltage.
You can remove <TRANSISTOR>Q7330</TRANSISTOR> and see if is short indeed.

Check all components and traces around <CHIP>U7300</CHIP>.
Change it, if nothing strange found.
